oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Jann Browne Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Jann Browne (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Jann Browne; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Jann Browne talks about living in California and being discovered by Dick Whitehouse from Curb Records -- (00:37) Browne talks about "Tell Me Why" and how the album was recorded in Los Angeles and Nashville -- (01:06) Browne talks about her small hometown inspiration to "Aint No Train" and Pat Gallagher -- (01:47) Collie and Browne discuss Browne working with Asleep at the Wheel after opening a show and performing an encore with them first time they performed together -- (02:47) Browne jokes performing on stage with a large man -- (03:01) "'Til a Tear Becomes a Rose" is discussed as Browne's most difficult song to record on the album -- (03:34) Browne and Collie discuss the photograph of her grandfather on the back of her album "Tell Me Why" -- (03:57) Browne talks about her family connection to country music , her grandparents being professional square dancers, and her experimentation of genres -- (04:44) Collie and Browne address how she lives close to Louisville and going there on weekends for the derby -- (05:04) Browne tells of how "Louisville" was inspired by a trip by Pat Gallagher visiting Louisville -- (05:34) "Mexican Wind" is discussed as Browne's favorite song and her strong romantic connection to being in the desert -- (06:15) Browne talks about her video taping for the music video of "Mexican Wind" and Emmylou Harris' contribution on both the song and Browne's life -- (07:11) Browne talks about the realization of the contributions she received on the album -- (07:24) Collie recaps the halfway point and Browne reveals her true name Jana Brown -- (08:17) Browne describes "Losing You" as a rockabilly track that would bring up the album -- (08:45) Browne talks about how Albert Lee, James Burton and others joining in on tracks without any idea how they album with form -- "You Aint Down Home" by Browne is discussed as being pulled from a compilation -- (10:44) "The One You Slip Around With" is joked about based on its writer Harlan Howard -- (10:58) Browne and Collie speaks on Harlan Howard and visiting the Grand Ole Opry and meeting Jan Howard -- (11:58) Browne tells of Howard performing "The One You Slip Around With" for her personally -- (12:14) Collie and Browne talk about Wanda Jackson and her writing primarily gospel tunes and Browne asking for her help on "I Forgot More Than You'll Ever Know" -- (14:02) Collie and Browne talk about "Lovebird" by Steve Spurgin and how he tailored it for Browne -- (15:03) Browne speaks about her part on New Grass Revival -- (15:21) Browne thanks Collie and the various people that worked on her album -- (15:52) Collie talks about creating a copy of the show for when shes family and Browne and Collie joke about compensation
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Browne, Jann; Collie, Biff;
